message.content:
We need to “net‐out” all of the transactions affecting the interest receivable balance. In other words, we “simulate” the ending balance in the interest receivable account (assuming that no prior balance existed) by adding (or subtracting) the “Interest Receivables” amounts that appear in the transactions. (When interest is “accrued” but “unpaid” it is added to the receivable balance so that an increase in receivables is shown as a use of cash.) 

Below is one step‐by‐step approach:

1. Scan the transactions for rows whose type is “Interest Receivables.”
2. List each “Interest Receivables” transaction by its amount (note that some transactions in other examples can be negative so as to “reduce” the receivable but in this case every such entry is positive):
  • Interest20240101001   420.08 
  • Interest20240102002   375.58 
  • Interest20240103003   346.68369627 
  • Interest20240104004   291.07612692 
  • Interest20240105005   235.21708718 
  • Interest20240106006   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240107007   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240108008   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240109009   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240110010   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240111011   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240112012   199.61708718 
  • Interest20240113013   190.71708718 
  • Interest20240114014   190.71708718 
  • Interest20240115015   164.01708718 
  • Interest20240116016   164.01708718 
  • Interest20240117017   164.01708718 
  • Interest20240118018   164.01708718 
  • Interest20240119019   164.01708718 
  • Interest20240120020   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240121021   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240122022   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240123023   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240124024   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240125025   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240126026   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240127027   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240128028   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240129029   135.53708718 
  • Interest20240130030   135.53708718 

3. Sum all the amounts. (In this problem the sum turns out to be 5893.92117706; when rounded to two decimals we get 5893.92.) 

Since an increase in an asset account (interest receivable) represents a use of cash in the operating cash flow statement, we then “report” the change as a negative number – that is, an “(Increase) in Interest Receivable of –5893.92.”

Thus the final answer is:

-------------------------------------------------
{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-5893.92"
  }
}

This is the net change from all the “Interest Receivables” transactions in the data.
